page.text: Bach Orchestral Suite No. 2, Movement 3: Gavotte I, II $bachpic.png, Johann Sebastian Bach
This Orchestral Suite is a collection of music written for dancing.
The first few lines of the piece now repeat. Listen as the trumpets reinforce the melody. $trumpet.jpg, trumpet
New melody now. Listen as the oboes and violins exchange prominence. $violin.png, violin
Listen for the viola and bass sections to fill out the harmony. $bass.png, string bass
The section will repeat shortly.
The section repeats from the beginning.
Again, listen to the violins and oboes. $oboe.png, oboe
The first Gavotte is now ending.
The second Gavotte begins. Note the new melody.
The violins and violas are most prominent here. See if you can hear the violas, which are lower in pitch than the violins. $viola.jpg, the viola, slightly larger than the violin
The first theme of the second Gavotte is about to repeat.
The first section of the second Gavotte begins to repeat.
Again, listen for both violins and violas stating the main theme.
The next section is about to begin.
The trumpets have a more pronounced influence in this section. Listen for them as they fanfare in the beginnings of phrases $trumpet.jpg, trumpet
The entire orchestra enters as the section nears its conclusion.
The second section is about to repeat.
The second section begins to repeat.
Again, listen for the combinations of instruments and their interplay.
The first Gavotte will repeat shortly.
The first Gavotte is repeating. Listen to the last notes of the three-note sequences as they have changed.
This part is the same as before, except that there is no repeat. The second section of the first Gavotte will follow shortly.
Again, the ends of three note sequences contain ornamental playing. $notes.jpg, three note sequence with markings for ornamental playing
The piece continues towards the end of the first Gavotte and concludes.
Bach Orchestral Suite No. 2, Movement 3: Gavotte I, II $bachpic.png, Johann Sebastian Bach
The first of two Gavottes begin.
A Gavotte is a strictly binary work with two repeating sections
We are in the A section
The A section now repeats
Notice that the piece returns to the dance-like music of the rest of the suite
The A section ends in the modulated key of A major
The B section now begins, and starts of more unsettled than the A section
This uneasiness is brought about by modulating from the beginning and not setting up a particular key
The uneasiness settles and some melodic elements from the A section return
Some modulation and resolution occurs quickly as the B section ends.
The section now repeats
Listen once again for the uneasiness and movement created by the constant modulation
The second Gavotte begins. Note the new melody.
Note the call and response in the melodic structure
The call is strong and stark, while the response is smooth and flowing.
The theme now repeats.
Call and response once again
Smooth flowing modulating lines contrast the boisterousness of the call and response
The section ends with call and response once again
The new section now begins, and starts off more uneasy than the A section
The call and response is less boisterous and begins to modulate
As the contrasting smooth lines enter, they no longer modulate.
The section now repeats
A gavotte is a lively French folk dance.
Liveliness is created with the beginning of melodies starting in-between measures, rather than at beginnings
A gavotte's melody generally begins on the third beat of the measure
The first gavotte now repeats itself again
This time, no repeats are followed, and the gavotte is played straight through
Notice once again melodies starting on beat three of measures
The next section now begins
This section is played once through as well.
The section ends and the movement comes to a close.
Bach Orchestral Suite No. 2, Movement 3: Gavotte I, II $bachpic.png, Johann Sebastian Bach
The Gavotte is a French folk dance. It is a strictly binary work with two repeating sections. $dance.png, dance
The first main theme now repeats. Listen as the trumpets reinforce it. $trumpet.png, trumpet
The end of the first theme modulates from D major to A major. A second theme will enter shortly.
A second theme begins. Listen as the oboes and violins exchange prominence. $oboe.png, oboe
The viola and bass sections to fill out the harmony. $bass.png, string bass
This section will repeat shortly.
The second section now repeats.
The violin and oboe once again take control of the melody. $violin.png, violin
The first of two Gavottes approaches its conclusion
The second Gavotte begins. Note the new melody.
Note the call and response in the melodic structure. The call is strong and stark, while the response is smooth and flowing.
The first theme of the second Gavotte is about to repeat.
The theme now repeats.
Both violin and viola state a flowing theme that contrasts with the boisterousness of the call and response. $viola.png, viola
The first section ends with call and response once again. A new theme will enter shortly.
The new section now begins more unsettled than the previous section due to constant modulation. Listen as the tonal center continues to shift.
The demonstration ends as this section comes to a close. Thank You.
The second section is about to repeat.
This Orchestral Suite is written for dancing. A Gavotte is a lively French folk dance. $dance. png,
Liveliness is created with the beginning of melodies starting in-between measures, rather than at beginnings.
The demonstration ends as this section comes to a close. Thank You.
